summary: emilia: read the first asoiaf book 9 times to make sure she was portraying daenerys right  d&d: said sam didn’t have a pov...
body:
emilia: read the first asoiaf book 9 times to make sure she was portraying daenerys right 

d&d: said sam didn’t have a pov chapter and kit harington had to remind them because they ‘kind of forgot’ 

antis: eMiLiA dOeSn’T uNdErStAnD tHe MaTeRiAl Or HeR oWn ChArAcTeR bUt D&d DoEs

me: emilia put more effort into getting things right in comparison to d&d because she actually cares about the fans and her character instead of d&d rushing through season 8 to get to star wars

This is NOT a spoiler-free blog.

blog.name: waking-dreams-of-harmony
blog.title: Headcanon is the new reality...
blog.description:
Hi there! My name is Ellie! Welcome to my tumblr!  Just thought I'd add a few things to know about me and my blog! If my url gives you any clues, at the heart of this tumblr, I'm a proud Harmony shipper through and through. And while I do still reblog HHR and Dan and Emma content (and I always will) you will find that the majority of my focus has shifted to Jonerys (Jon x Daenerys from Game of Thrones). And while you might have to do a little deep blogging to find my reblogs on these, I also ship--both passionately and casually--Cesare x Lucrezia, Mulder x Scully, Lizzington for a while until tptb started to mess with it, Baker x Lawson (Bawson), all the Sense8 ships though Kalagang is my #1, Clint x Natasha (Clintasha), Jane x Thor (Fosterson), Darcy x Loki (Tasertricks), Darcy x Steve (Shieldshock), Kili x Tauriel (Kiliel), Superman x Wonder Woman (Superwonder), and more than I have space for or the memory to list. 
I do my best to tag every post so that if something is your notp, it's nsfw, or it's triggering, you can blacklist it. That said, if you follow me and there is something that you need tagged in order to make it a happy place for you to explore, come into my inbox and let me know :) You will also see a lot of politically charged reblogs in support of women, the queer/gender-queer and trans community, BLM, Muslims, POC, Jewish people, the mentally ill, and austistic people. I'm strongly pro choice, pro inter-sectional feminism, and refuse to call the angry cheeto currently living in the white house president. If anything like that offends you, this might not be the right blog for you.
Last little few things to throw out there: I'm 35, I plan to adopt at least 4 cats (or more) at some point and be that cat lady everyone's always whispering about, and I tend to greet and converse with everyone I meet like an overeager puppy. 
Whew! Sorry for the long intro folks! Please enjoy your time here, and remember, you're always welcome to come in and say hi!

summary: Since David Benioff wrote Deadpool (or what was "Deadpool") in Wolverine Origins, I wanted to cover on why did folks think...
caption:
Since David Benioff wrote Deadpool (or what was “Deadpool”) in Wolverine Origins, I wanted to cover on why did folks think Emilia just didn’t know Daenerys at all (and how folks didn’t blame the writers ahem: one being David Benioff.) A decade ago Benioff wrote the Wolverine script and decided to subvert expectations by making Deadpool a mute villain. With comic readers going WTF??? this was a mercenary with a big mouth who couldn’t shut up! And Ryan Reynolds, a bigtime Deadpool fan was told to stuff it and do the work if he was to continue Deadpool into future flicks. Ryan who did know what Deadpool was about, played THE DEADPOOL that we all know and love in his films.

So come on folks….Emilia KNOWS Daenerys. EOM.

summary: 10 Daenerys endings that would have made more sense.
body:
10 Daenerys endings that would have made more sense.

In order from happiest to saddest.

1. Happily Ever After

Simple. Dany wins and successfully fixes and rules Westeros.

2. Happily Ever After?

Dany wins but realizes the problems plaguing Westeros is more than she anticipated. Wonders if it was all worth it.

3. Dany retires back to Maureen

After her army gets devastated in the battle vs the Night King (and they don’t miraculously regenerate), she makes the choice to sail back for Maureen, satisfied that she saved her homeland. Sansa is left to deal with Cersi and actually earn the title of Queen.

4. Dany and co start a new kingdom.

Dany, Jon, Sansa, Tyrion, and the others band together under a new kingdom, uniting the free folk, Winterfell, and the Iron Isles to fight against Cerci. Run Democraticly.

5. Dany dies in the battle vs the Night King.

Dies in a dragon battle. Dies saving Jon. Or Sansa. Or Arya. Or her dragons.

6. Dany dies in the battle for King’s Landing.

She doesn’t burn the city to the ground, making the fight a bit harder. The Golden Company is an actual threat.

7. Dany gets assassinated.

Anti-climatic but easy to achieve when she is surrounded by people who don’t like her.

8. Dany dies in childbirth.

The hints of her getting pregnant actually come to fruition. Complications from her previous pregnancy and her insistence on staying in the action and not taking time to relax costs her her life.

9. Dany goes “crazy” trying to prove herself to the people of Westeros.

Instead of her moral swing hinging on some weird jealousy, it comes from being egged on by Jon and the people of the north who are tired of Cerci’s shit. They tell her she won’t be respected as Queen unless she burns Cerci’s forces. She does.

10. Dany is killed by one of her Dragons

Yea this is also anti climatic, but Drogon acidentally stepping on Dany is more relalistic than the redicoulous finalle.

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: In "Game of Thrones", Daenerys Targaryen survives a fire and hatches three dragons. In "Harry Potter", when a Phoenix bursts...
body: In “Game of Thrones”, Daenerys Targaryen survives a fire and hatches three dragons. In “Harry Potter”, when a Phoenix bursts into flame and is reborn in its own ashes, that day is called a Burning Day. Dany being spiritually reborn in fire and blood is her own Burning Day.

reblog.comment: In “Game of Thrones”, Daenerys Targaryen survives a fire and hatches three dragons. In “Harry Potter”, when a Phoenix bursts into flame and is reborn in its own ashes, that day is called a Burning Day. Dany being spiritually reborn in fire and blood is her own Burning Day.

blog.name: lupinusalbus
blog.title: Lupinus Albus
blog.description:
Speculations about Game of Thrones...
(mostly the show)

summary: The Poor Handling of Jon’s true Heritage Pretty Much Wrecked the Ending
title: The Poor Handling of Jon’s true Heritage Pretty Much Wrecked the Ending
body:
I think a big part of the problems with season eight was the poor execution of Jon’s character arc, more specifically the impact of Sam and Bran’s revelation about his true lineage.  Although the earlier seasons were pretty much a faithful adaptation of the books (with some big omissions), Benioff & Weiss got to the point where they had to work with less of a blueprint.  Particularly in seasons seven and eight, their goal was to wrap up the series (sooner than what was needed), by hitting the big plot points and then kind of working backwards to fill in a few blanks.  They could not take the time to tell the involved, character driven story that is Martin’s trademark, where the inner psychology of the character is driving the dialogue and the developments. Instead they went for spectacle like what we would get from an action movie.  So, for example, if Dany being killed by Jon is the spectacle planned for episode 6, they did the bare minimum by keeping Jon reduced to kind of a placeholder who was mouthing the same old lines about “his queen” until they could get him to the point where he suddenly goes off the rails by killing Dany. 

There was very little intrigue about Jon’s Targaryen Bloodline simply because his character was a now mostly a cardboard cut-out instead of a well-rounded person.  Even during season seven, most of his talk consisted very one-dimensional statements about the threat of the Night King which turned him into an almost annoying “prophet of doom” type caricature of himself.  Not that the advance of the Night King was not what Jon should have been focusing on, but his character lost much of what had made it so great.  His dialogues were almost exclusively about the Night King and came off as wooden because he was not given very much nuance.  His supposed romance with Dany is a great case in point, and still comes across as very ambiguous. 

The earlier seasons were very much about Jon Snow’s backstory, which is rich with pathos and intrigue even in the show.  Jon’s parents, although we only see them briefly, are major figures because Robert’s Rebellion and Robert Baratheon’s ascension are major drivers of the entire story.  Rhaegar’s motives, which we never got to hear any more about, are left shrouded in mystery by the show, even though the saga and details from the Tower of Joy are major revelations from the earlier seasons - which are shown as being intimately connected to Jon’s Kingship.  Benioff and Weiss did a good job handling these essential plot points in season six, but then just dropped it all so that they could finish the series with abbreviated seasons for seven and eight.  Many viewers were willing to overlook the huge problems with season seven because they believed that season eight was going to bring everything together, including the deeper mysteries of Jon’s birth and resurrection.

Instead they likely designed episodes five and six as “showcases” for Dany’s descent into genocide and then the necessity of Jon killing her.  The essential tragedy of this for Jon is pretty much skipped over in favor of giving us  a Dany-centric arc in the final season.  The first episode is about her triumphant arrival at Winterfell.  She shares her dragons with Jon, only to find out right before the big battle that her love interest is her nephew and more importantly the rightful heir.  Dany gets a cold reception in the North and is somewhat usurped by Sansa and also eclipsed by Jon’s popularity.  It’s all about her rather than Jon; but it could have been about both if the writers had taken the time and effort to do justice to the full story.

Jon Snow in “The Bells”.   His identity/moral crisis should have been a centerpiece of season eight.


The Starks do triumph in the end in that the remaining characters all live and have new beginnings, but the ending feels unsatisfying because the plotting makes them appear as footnotes to Dany’s story.  This is a big reason why the ending feels muddled.   We can see the “bones” of Martin’s story, and how the Starks are going to be the next chapter of his saga (if ever told), yet their characters have been given short shrift because the focus was on Dany’s arc.  The story lost so much of the richness and complexity of the Stark family, including their mystical roots with the North and the Direwolves.  In particular, Jon’s story was central to the “Song of Ice and Fire”, but the show lost the fascinating threads of what he was really all about.

How much better could Game of Thrones have been had Jon’s personal qualities vs. those of Dany been made a centerpiece of the story!  Even Varys’s short-lived “plot” was inexplicably presented as a minor sideshow when it should have been a major development for Jon and the Starks.

reblog.comment:
I think a big part of the problems with season eight was the poor execution of Jon’s character arc, more specifically the impact of Sam and Bran’s revelation about his true lineage.  Although the earlier seasons were pretty much a faithful adaptation of the books (with some big omissions), Benioff & Weiss got to the point where they had to work with less of a blueprint.  Particularly in seasons seven and eight, their goal was to wrap up the series (sooner than what was needed), by hitting the big plot points and then kind of working backwards to fill in a few blanks.  They could not take the time to tell the involved, character driven story that is Martin’s trademark, where the inner psychology of the character is driving the dialogue and the developments. Instead they went for spectacle like what we would get from an action movie.  So, for example, if Dany being killed by Jon is the spectacle planned for episode 6, they did the bare minimum by keeping Jon reduced to kind of a placeholder who was mouthing the same old lines about “his queen” until they could get him to the point where he suddenly goes off the rails by killing Dany. 

There was very little intrigue about Jon’s Targaryen Bloodline simply because his character was a now mostly a cardboard cut-out instead of a well-rounded person.  Even during season seven, most of his talk consisted very one-dimensional statements about the threat of the Night King which turned him into an almost annoying “prophet of doom” type caricature of himself.  Not that the advance of the Night King was not what Jon should have been focusing on, but his character lost much of what had made it so great.  His dialogues were almost exclusively about the Night King and came off as wooden because he was not given very much nuance.  His supposed romance with Dany is a great case in point, and still comes across as very ambiguous. 

The earlier seasons were very much about Jon Snow’s backstory, which is rich with pathos and intrigue even in the show.  Jon’s parents, although we only see them briefly, are major figures because Robert’s Rebellion and Robert Baratheon’s ascension are major drivers of the entire story.  Rhaegar’s motives, which we never got to hear any more about, are left shrouded in mystery by the show, even though the saga and details from the Tower of Joy are major revelations from the earlier seasons - which are shown as being intimately connected to Jon’s Kingship.  Benioff and Weiss did a good job handling these essential plot points in season six, but then just dropped it all so that they could finish the series with abbreviated seasons for seven and eight.  Many viewers were willing to overlook the huge problems with season seven because they believed that season eight was going to bring everything together, including the deeper mysteries of Jon’s birth and resurrection.

Instead they likely designed episodes five and six as “showcases” for Dany’s descent into genocide and then the necessity of Jon killing her.  The essential tragedy of this for Jon is pretty much skipped over in favor of giving us  a Dany-centric arc in the final season.  The first episode is about her triumphant arrival at Winterfell.  She shares her dragons with Jon, only to find out right before the big battle that her love interest is her nephew and more importantly the rightful heir.  Dany gets a cold reception in the North and is somewhat usurped by Sansa and also eclipsed by Jon’s popularity.  It’s all about her rather than Jon; but it could have been about both if the writers had taken the time and effort to do justice to the full story.

Jon Snow in “The Bells”.   His identity/moral crisis should have been a centerpiece of season eight.


The Starks do triumph in the end in that the remaining characters all live and have new beginnings, but the ending feels unsatisfying because the plotting makes them appear as footnotes to Dany’s story.  This is a big reason why the ending feels muddled.   We can see the “bones” of Martin’s story, and how the Starks are going to be the next chapter of his saga (if ever told), yet their characters have been given short shrift because the focus was on Dany’s arc.  The story lost so much of the richness and complexity of the Stark family, including their mystical roots with the North and the Direwolves.  In particular, Jon’s story was central to the “Song of Ice and Fire”, but the show lost the fascinating threads of what he was really all about.

How much better could Game of Thrones have been had Jon’s personal qualities vs. those of Dany been made a centerpiece of the story!  Even Varys’s short-lived “plot” was inexplicably presented as a minor sideshow when it should have been a major development for Jon and the Starks.

I think a big part of the problems with season eight was the poor execution of Jon’s character arc, more specifically the impact of Sam and Bran’s revelation about his true lineage.  Although the earlier seasons were pretty much a faithful adaptation of the books (with some big omissions), Benioff & Weiss got to the point where they had to work with less of a blueprint.  Particularly in seasons seven and eight, their goal was to wrap up the series (sooner than what was needed), by hitting the big plot points and then kind of working backwards to fill in a few blanks.  They could not take the time to tell the involved, character driven story that is Martin’s trademark, where the inner psychology of the character is driving the dialogue and the developments. blog.name: thefreshprinceofdragonstone
blog.title: I'll stay here alone with my genius

summary: I know this is extremely petty and I'm not proud of it, but it really does give me satisfaction that Cersei Lannister knew what...
body: I know this is extremely petty and I’m not proud of it, but it really does give me satisfaction that Cersei Lannister knew what it felt like to birth a living child, to sit on the Iron Throne and to die comforted and protected by the man she loved, and that Daenerys didn’t get to know what any of that felt like.

reblog.comment: I know this is extremely petty and I’m not proud of it, but it really does give me satisfaction that Cersei Lannister knew what it felt like to birth a living child, to sit on the Iron Throne and to die comforted and protected by the man she loved, and that Daenerys didn’t get to know what any of that felt like.

blog.name: notthehound
blog.title: Game Of Thrones Stuff
blog.description: There are no ships on GOT. I hope!

tags: why did she have to be his aunt not hs cousin
summary: The feels. Gloriously done. I still can’t figure out if he sacrificed his duty/honor by killing his Queen to save his love...
body: The feels. Gloriously done. I still can’t figure out if he sacrificed his duty/honor by killing his Queen to save his love (family) or if he sacrificed his love (Daenerys) to do his duty/honor to be the shield that guards the realm of men, or even just to protect his family.

reblog.comment: The feels. Gloriously done. I still can’t figure out if he sacrificed his duty/honor by killing his Queen to save his love (family) or if he sacrificed his love (Daenerys) to do his duty/honor to be the shield that guards the realm of men, or even just to protect his family.
